stories.headline: Thunder Hold Off Resilient Pacers, Capture First NBA Championship for Oklahoma City
stories.summary: The Oklahoma City Thunder have won their first NBA championship after holding off a resilient effort by the Indiana Pacers. This victory marks a major milestone for the team.

stories.headline: Chicago Survivor of Concentration Camp Wants to Erect Memorial to Bosnian War Victims
stories.summary: A Chicago survivor of a concentration camp is advocating for the creation of a memorial dedicated to victims of the Bosnian War. The initiative aims to raise awareness and honor those who suffered during the conflict.

stories.headline: Near Record Highs Expected Today as Heat Wave Lingers
stories.summary: Chicago and surrounding areas are expected to experience near record high temperatures today as a lingering heat wave continues. Residents are advised to take precautions against the prolonged heat.

stories.headline: Trump Floats Idea of 'Regime Change' After Strikes on Iran
stories.summary: Following recent strikes on Iran, former President Trump has suggested the possibility of regime change. The proposal has sparked debate amid ongoing tensions in the region.

stories.headline: The Truth About 'Underground Chicago'
stories.summary: Viral videos show thrill-seekers uncovering caves and even rave parties while searching for a network of tunnels beneath Chicago. The tunnels exist, but experts say the videos do not accurately represent the claims made by so-called 'urban explorers.'

stories.headline: Teacher retention remains challenge
stories.summary: Despite salary increases and some improvements in hiring new educators, many school districts continue to struggle with teacher retention, especially for special education teachers. A University of Arkansas report highlights that retention rates have only moderately stabilized and pandemic effects linger. Experts discuss the complexity of improving education staffing.

stories.headline: Brazilian celebration
stories.summary: A large rainbow flag was unfolded during the annual Pride parade in São Paulo, Brazil, celebrating LGBTQ+ Pride Month. The event attracted revelers in joyous festivities marking diversity and inclusion.

stories.headline: Dog attack heightens call for aid, regulations
stories.summary: Ivy Wood highlights the increasing incidents of stray and abandoned dog attacks, stressing the need for better resources and regulations to handle the animals safely. The article calls attention to community concerns about animal control and public safety amid more frequent dog attacks.

stories.headline: World reacts to US attack against Iran
stories.summary: The international community responded to the US airstrikes on Iran's nuclear program, raising questions about future conflict and the impact on regional stability. The US cited protection of its interests and defense against Iran's threats, but Iran and allies condemned the strikes as aggressive and illegitimate. The situation remains tense with fears of escalation.

stories.headline: US Rep. Crawford praises Trump for strikes on Iran
stories.summary: U.S. Representative Rick Crawford expressed strong support for President Trump's decision to carry out precision strikes on Iranian nuclear sites, describing them as measured and demonstrating resolve in protecting U.S. interests. He emphasized that the administration will continue efforts to counter threats from Iran.

stories.headline: Tourism agency to get private call spaces
stories.summary: The Arkansas Department of Parks, Heritage and Tourism is adding five private phone booths at the Arkansas Heritage building to provide space for phone conversations. This move is part of a broader transition as some employees relocate, aiming to improve work environment and privacy.

stories.headline: Jury selection expected to begin this week in 2023 fair shooting
stories.summary: Jury selection is set to start in a Dallas County court for the 2023 State Fair of Texas shooting case. Cameron Turner, 23, is charged with three counts of aggravated assault with a deadly weapon after gunfire erupted inside the Tower Building during the fair, injuring three people. Authorities continue investigations into how the weapon entered the venue. Turner was arrested quickly and was defending himself and his family during the incident, according to statements.

stories.headline: U.S. advances in Gold Cup
stories.summary: The U.S. men's national soccer team defeated Haiti 2-1 in a tense CONCACAF Gold Cup quarterfinal match in Arlington. The victory advances the U.S. to the tournament's semifinals, continuing their pursuit of the championship. The match was highly competitive and closely contested by both teams.

stories.headline: Iran: Response coming
stories.summary: Following U.S. and Israeli strikes on Iran's nuclear facilities, U.S. officials say they want to restart diplomatic talks. Iran's U.N. ambassador and Supreme Leader have condemned the strikes and warned of military responses. U.S. Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth stated the U.S. does not seek war but will consider Iran a target if it attacks U.S. forces. The Trump administration sent messages signaling a willingness to talk with Iran despite ongoing tensions and strikes.

stories.headline: Leader wants '100% reset'
stories.summary: Dallas Park Board President Arun Agarwal calls for a complete '100% reset' of the organizations managing Fair Park. This follows issues such as misused donor funds and contract disputes. The nonprofit managing Fair Park First, which raised about $60 million for refurbishing the park, will retain its fundraising role but the city plans to terminate its contract with its subcontractor Oak View Group. The city seeks a public process to restore trust and oversee fundraising and operations at Fair Park.

stories.headline: FDA ends Biden-era policy of DNA exports to China
stories.summary: The Trump administration's FDA has reversed Biden-era policies by halting companies from exporting clinical trials DNA samples to China. The decision was driven by security concerns over potential misuse and transfer of genetic material for research without proper consent. The FDA Commissioner acknowledged the risks and ended the program to protect sensitive genetic data.

stories.headline: Charities worry about tax increase despite Senate move
stories.summary: Despite Senate Republicans removing a House-passed tax increase on private foundations, charities still express concern about potential tax hikes that could affect private resources for giving and services. Foundations and philanthropic organizations warn that such changes could undermine charitable giving and reduce government funding support.

stories.headline: Trump order triggers war powers showdown
stories.summary: President Trump's unilateral decision to strike Iran's nuclear facilities has reignited a constitutional debate over the war powers of the president versus Congress. Lawmakers from both parties express concern about the degree of presidential authority to conduct military actions without congressional approval, with calls for impeachment and war powers resolution being discussed.

stories.headline: Midnight Hammer destroys Iran nuclear sites, Tehran threatens retaliation
stories.summary: The U.S. launched Operation Midnight Hammer, targeting and destroying Iran's nuclear sites, prompting Tehran to threaten retaliation. The strike aimed to cripple Tehran's nuclear ambitions while raising tension in the Middle East. American military forces remain on high alert as Iran's allies condemn the attack but offer no aid. Key military and government figures emphasize the seriousness of the situation and the possibility of wider conflict.

stories.headline: Wavering MAGA base draws red line on war
stories.summary: Supporters of President Trump who are part of the MAGA movement are divided over his decision to bomb Iran's nuclear facilities. While staunch supporters like Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene back the move, a surgical strike has sparked debate among the base, with some expressing hesitation about engaging in broader military conflict.

stories.headline: U.S. snub: Europeans moving to local tech
stories.summary: In Berlin, a charity promotes alternatives to U.S. tech firms as Europeans seek to limit their exposure to American digital services amid geopolitical tensions. The rise in interest follows President Donald Trump's second term announcements and trade war impacts. European users are increasingly using homegrown email, messaging, and search services to reduce dependence on U.S. tech giants. Notably, Tesla's Elon Musk and other prominent tech leaders have influenced this shift.

stories.headline: U.S. warns about 'heightened threat environment' after targeted strikes
stories.summary: Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth declared that the U.S. bombers obliterated major Iranian nuclear sites at Fordow, Natanz, and Isfahan, responding firmly to Iran's activities. The U.S. is fully prepared to counter any Iranian retaliation, prioritizing the safety of service members and civilians. President Donald Trump announced the strikes, stating that all Iranian planes are now outside Iranian air space.

stories.headline: Apartments near OK under Live Local Act
stories.summary: The city of West Palm Beach is set to approve its first development built under the Live Local Act, bypassing some local restrictions to increase affordable housing. The act offers developers incentives to set aside 40% of a project's units for lower rental costs. Miller Permitting and Land Development managed the Northwood apartment complex project, using the Live Local Act process despite initial city resistance.

stories.headline: Sonic boom: Space Coast economy now among fastest-growing in US
stories.summary: Brevard County's economy, known as the Space Coast, is experiencing rapid growth despite past concerns about the end of the space shuttle program. Growth momentum was aided by local leaders' efforts, former astronauts, and community rallies supporting the Kennedy Space Center. Population projections indicate that the master-planned community Viera will more than double by 2045. The area's connection to the space program continues to drive economic optimism.

stories.headline: Tariffs threaten to entangle Ayotte in N.H.
stories.summary: New Hampshire's former governor Kelly Ayotte faces political challenges due to her stance on President Trump's trade war tariffs. While she supports the president on various issues, her position on tariffs has caused unease among local leaders and constituents, complicating her future political prospects.

stories.headline: Next step for nonverbal autistic teen: MIT
stories.summary: Nonverbal autistic teen Viraj Dhanda was recently accepted to MIT, overcoming significant challenges associated with his autism diagnosis. His story highlights progress in understanding and supporting autistic students, with his father's dedicated support playing a key role in this milestone achievement.

stories.headline: Lawmakers question Trump’s unilateral strikes
stories.summary: Congressional members are divided over President Trump's decision to strike Iranian nuclear sites without consulting Congress. Both Democrats and Republicans express concerns regarding the legality, justification, and potential consequences of the military action, highlighting ongoing political debate.

stories.headline: A day of threats, warnings
stories.summary: Following a series of US strikes against Iranian nuclear sites, Tehran has vowed retaliation while Washington warns against any reprisal actions. The situation remains tense with Iran threatening to strike back, raising concerns over escalating conflict and stability in the Middle East.

stories.headline: As rents go up, money for vouchers may plummet
stories.summary: In Massachusetts, housing authorities have stopped issuing new Section 8 vouchers due to funding constraints linked to stagnant federal funding and soaring rents. This pause may exacerbate waitlists and limit access to affordable housing assistance, impacting thousands of low-income tenants in one of the most expensive housing markets in the U.S.

stories.headline: US: Strikes caused 'severe damage' to Iranian nuclear sites
stories.summary: Pentagon officials reported that three of Iran's nuclear sites sustained 'severe damage' from US strikes, though the Trump administration emphasized it did not intend to start an all-out war. President Trump claimed he 'completely and totally obliterated' three sites. However, it is still uncertain whether Iran retains some nuclear capability. Officials described a tightly coordinated attack involving multiple military assets, with Iran assessing the damage at facilities in Fordo, Natanz, and Isfahan. The situation remains tense with diplomatic efforts focused on avoiding further escalation.

stories.headline: Search called off for 2 after 6 killed by capsized boat amid Tahoe storm
stories.summary: The Coast Guard suspended the search for two missing people after a boat capsized in rough waters near D.L. Bliss State Park, resulting in six confirmed deaths. The vessel, a 27-foot Chris-Craft, overturned amid high winds and rough waves. Six adults were rescued, but the fate of two remains unknown. Authorities continue investigations surrounding the circumstances of the incident, with a focus on whether life jackets were worn by those involved.

stories.headline: Democrats blast Trump's Iran military action, urge briefings
stories.summary: Democratic leaders sharply criticized President Donald Trump's decision to bomb Iranian nuclear sites without congressional approval, arguing that he should have sought authorization before military action. Senator Adam Schiff and Senator Alex Padilla expressed concern about the risks of escalating conflict and the need for bipartisan briefings. Schiff emphasized that any further military action must be approved by Congress to avoid risking a wider war and putting American lives in jeopardy.

stories.headline: With strike his predecessors avoided, Trump takes huge gamble
stories.summary: Over two decades, the United States avoided direct military strikes on Iran to slow its nuclear program through sanctions and diplomacy. However, President Donald Trump launched a sudden military attack on Iranian nuclear sites, marking a significant departure from past policies. This bold move, involving a show of force with B-2 bombers and cruise missiles, carries major risks of escalating war in the Middle East. The prime target was deeply buried nuclear enrichment centers, reflecting the seriousness of the operation.

stories.headline: Bridge work brings fresh paint blues
stories.summary: Restoration work on the Walnut Street Bridge in Chattanooga uncovered a color change on the pedestrian bridge's paint, sparking debate among locals. City officials explained that the new paint color is a close match to the original 1990s 'Riverpark blue' color, but not an exact replica, causing some confusion among residents familiar with the bridge’s previous look. The bridge restoration aims to preserve the historic landmark while respecting its aesthetic heritage.

stories.headline: Attack on Iran brings wider conflict worries
stories.summary: The world is concerned as the United States strikes Iranian nuclear sites, raising questions about Tehran's nuclear program and potential military responses. Experts warn of a possible wider regional conflict with Iran coordinating with Russia and tens of thousands of American troops stationed in the Middle East. Iran's U.N. ambassador indicated the U.S. decision to destroy Iranian diplomacy might escalate tensions, while the Trump administration initially proposed restarting direct talks with Iran despite recent attacks.

stories.headline: Arkansas may not be ready for an anti-abortion monument
stories.summary: Arkansas officials face challenges as an artist plans to design an anti-abortion memorial near the Arkansas State Capitol. The proposed monument, envisioned as a long wall of plants and a Bible quotation, is intended to serve as a counterpoint to a nearby monument supporting abortion rights. The project reflects ongoing local and national debates over abortion, with legislative and public opinions playing roles in the monument's acceptance and future.

stories.headline: Oil giants make use of speech as defense
stories.summary: Oil companies are defending themselves in court by invoking their free speech rights against climate lawsuits, challenging anti-SLAPP laws intended to protect critics from costly legal battles. They argue that climate lawsuits against them should be dismissed as infringements on their constitutional protections under the First Amendment. Legal experts note this tactic signifies a reversal of the original intent of these laws, highlighting a strategic shift in high-stakes legal fights involving environmental accountability.

stories.headline: Michigan lawmakers react to U.S. airstrikes
stories.summary: Michigan’s elected officials showed a split response along political party lines to the U.S. airstrikes in Iran. Republicans praised President Trump’s decisive action, while Democrats criticized the lack of congressional approval and warned about the risk of prolonged conflict in the Middle East. Two Michigan U.S. senators, Gary Peters and Elissa Slotkin, emphasized the need to brief Congress and voiced concerns about escalating conflict without further approval.

stories.headline: Attack foiled, gunman killed at Wayne church
stories.summary: A gunman’s attack at a Wayne church was foiled, with the assailant killed on site. Details on the incident emphasize quick response and successful prevention of potential tragedy at the religious site.

stories.headline: Michigan State Police urge vigilance after U.S. bombs Iran
stories.summary: The Michigan State Police reminded residents to remain vigilant and cautious following U.S. military strikes on Iran’s nuclear sites, due to potential retaliation concerns. The Michigan Public Information Officer confirmed increased security monitoring, although specific security measures were not disclosed. Authorities emphasized community safety and advised contacting local police if suspicious activity is observed.

stories.headline: U.S. warns of ‘heightened threat environment’ after targeted strikes
stories.summary: Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth announced that U.S. bombers “obliterated” Iran’s three major nuclear facilities at Fordow, Natanz, and Isfahan in a series of air strikes on June 21, aiming to prevent Iran from continuing its nuclear program. President Donald Trump declared that Iran could face "far greater" attacks if it does not make peace, emphasizing the seriousness of the military action and the U.S. military’s readiness to respond to any retaliation.

stories.headline: US used decoys, deception to bomb nuclear sites without detection
stories.summary: In an unprecedented covert operation, US pilots dropped 30,000-pound bombs guided by stealth tactics to bomb Iranian nuclear sites, employing decoys and deception to avoid detection by Iranian forces. This precision strike was aimed at significantly damaging Iran's nuclear program. The operation involved the use of advanced technology and strategies including the deployment of stealth bombers and fighter jets.

stories.headline: Alaska Rainbow Elders support one another with coffee, conversation and community
stories.summary: LGBTQ+ members aged 60s to 80s meet weekly at the Anchorage Senior Activity Center to socialize and provide mutual support through aging. The group, Alaska Rainbow Elders, offers a safe space for older LGBTQ+ individuals to connect, share experiences and navigate challenges, including health updates and social isolation. The initiative addresses the need for community especially as members age and face varying life circumstances.

stories.headline: Alarm grows as US enters war
stories.summary: The world is grappling with the United States' insertion into Israel's war by attacking Iranian nuclear sites, an operation that raises urgent questions about Iran's nuclear program and how its military might respond. Experts warn that worldwide efforts to contain the spread of nuclear weapons could be at stake, as Iran has told the U.S. that crossing certain lines would provoke bombing. Tensions are escalating with fears of a wider regional conflict, and there are political and military cautious statements and strategic talks ongoing.

stories.headline: Here's how Iran could retaliate
stories.summary: Iran has warned the US not to enter the fight against Israel after strikes on Iranian nuclear sites. Tehran has built extensive missile and military capabilities and may target US assets in the Middle East or regional allies as retaliation against American strikes. The article outlines possible Iranian responses including missile and drone attacks and highlights the strategic significance of the Strait of Hormuz.

stories.headline: Strike on Iran casts doubt on whether U.S. was ever serious about talks
stories.summary: President Donald Trump had appeared to embrace hopes for a diplomatic end to the war between Israel and Iran just days ago. However, after Iran's nuclear sites were attacked, questions arose about the sincerity of the U.S. commitment to negotiations. Less than 48 hours after calling off talks, large bombers delivered the most destructive conventional payloads on Iranian nuclear facilities. There is doubt whether diplomats might get both sides to agree on a ceasefire, considering the months of preparation for military action before the strike.

stories.headline: U.S. ENTERS ISRAEL'S WAR AGAINST IRAN
stories.summary: The United States bombed three nuclear sites in Iran early Sunday morning, bringing the U.S. directly into Israel's war with Iran. The attacks by U.S. warplanes and submarines caused severe damage to Iran's nuclear sites, including its two major uranium enrichment centers. It remains unclear whether Iran's nuclear capability was entirely destroyed. The attack followed days of uncertainty about President Donald Trump's intentions and an Israeli strike on June 13 that began the conflict.

stories.headline: Opinion: Trump's Iran gamble could be the boost his presidency needs — or ruin it
stories.summary: President Trump's decision to bomb Iran's nuclear sites was a high-stakes gamble that could either breathe new life into his presidency or cause irreparable damage. While Trump's actions have troubled some, they might garner the consensus needed with the world's biggest democracies. However, with public opinion divided — only 42% approving of Trump’s job performance and 54% disapproving — the gamble carries significant political risk, especially as his popularity was declining fast even before the strike.

stories.headline: 6 dead, 2 missing after storm capsizes boat on Lake Tahoe
stories.summary: A severe storm caused a 27-foot Chris-Craft vessel to capsize on Lake Tahoe Saturday afternoon near D.L. Bliss State Park. Rescue efforts continued for two missing people while six others died due to the incident. Winds up to 35 mph and rough waters contributed to the tragedy. The El Dorado County Sheriff's Office confirmed several reports of capsized vessels in South Lake Tahoe, and dive teams have resumed their search for the missing.

stories.headline: U.S. bombs Iran, joins Israel in war
stories.summary: The United States has joined Israel in military action against Iran by dropping a 30,000-pound bomb on a uranium enrichment site, escalating tensions in the Middle East. President Trump stated that three nuclear sites were completely obliterated. Iran vows to respond to the aggression. The Trump administration emphasizes diplomatic talks with Iran but stresses that the U.S. does not seek war. Bay Area Democrats criticize the President for acting without congressional approval and call for restraint.

stories.headline: Troops ‘grossly’ underused in L.A.
stories.summary: Less than 20% of the nearly 5,000 National Guard and Marine troops deployed to Los Angeles were actually on the ground during the recent city unrest, according to a state official. The deployment cost $134 million and raised questions about the justification and utilization of these forces. A former National Guard commander called the situation "awful" in an interview, indicating dissatisfaction with how the troops were used.

stories.headline: Battling Canada’s Wildfires
stories.summary: British Columbia farmers are facing disruptions as wildfires threaten their livestock and land, and they are seeking assistance to manage the crisis brought on by these severe fires.

stories.headline: By Entering War, President Is Testing the Unity of His Coalition
stories.summary: President Trump has escalated military action against Iran by ordering a strike on critical Iranian nuclear sites, testing the unity of his ideological coalition. While his base largely approved, the president faced criticism from some allies and expressed limited intentions to continue the conflict. The move impacts U.S. relations in the Middle East and the broader political landscape.

stories.headline: U.S., Claiming 'Severe Damage,' Warns Iran Not to Strike Back
stories.summary: The United States has warned Iran not to retaliate following a series of surgical strikes by American B-2 bombers and missiles targeting Iran's nuclear sites, which caused what American officials described as "severe damage." Iran reserves all options to defend its interests. The article details the background and responses from various leaders, including President Trump and Israeli officials, and the impact on Iran's nuclear program and regional tensions.

stories.headline: Everybody Dance Now
stories.summary: A piece detailing a program at a nightclub in Brussels designed to reduce loneliness among seniors by encouraging them to engage in social dancing and activities.

stories.headline: New Take on a Sanskrit Epic
stories.summary: The theater company New Yam, led by Sujit Singh, presents a fresh adaptation of the Mahabharata that explores contemporary issues while honoring traditional roots.

stories.headline: The Rangers in Descent
stories.summary: The New York Rangers hockey team has endured one of their worst records in decades, sparking questions about performance and prospects for next season.

stories.headline: Chinese Dream Slipping Away
stories.summary: China’s path to prosperity is challenged by growth and education issues. The country’s youth are feeling disillusioned as economic and social barriers limit their aspirations, affecting the nation's broader development goals.

stories.headline: A Guide to the N.B.A. Draft
stories.summary: A detailed guide profiling the strengths, weaknesses, and outlook for the 2025 NBA draft prospects, offering insights for fans and teams ahead of the draft.

stories.headline: Thomas L. Friedman
stories.summary: Opinion piece or column by Thomas L. Friedman covering an undetailed topic related to international or political commentary.

stories.headline: German Far Right Glosses Agenda as It Expands
stories.summary: The AfD, Germany’s far-right political party, has expanded its influence beyond its traditional strongholds, spreading into the country’s western regions. Despite controversy and once being unwelcome, the party continues to push its agenda, capitalizing on nationalist and anti-immigrant sentiments to gain political ground.

stories.headline: Two-Stepping Onto the Playlist
stories.summary: Black Southern line dance culture inspires a new podcast series, "Boots on the Ground," which highlights rich traditions and contemporary stories in dance music.

stories.headline: Social Safety Net Is Fraying
stories.summary: The federal Job Corps program is struggling amid political disputes and funding challenges during the Trump administration, causing concerns about support for youth and workforce development.

stories.headline: Tesla Debuts Robotaxi Service
stories.summary: Tesla has launched a new robotaxi service using vehicles with advanced self-driving capabilities, rolling out a limited basis with strict safety monitoring to ensure autonomous operations.

stories.headline: Cuomo’s Complicated Legacy
stories.summary: An analysis of the former governor Andrew Cuomo’s controversial career, focusing on both his political successes and the scandals that tainted his legacy in New York City and state politics.

stories.headline: The Race to Outdo Ozempic, and the Next Drug
stories.summary: Doctors and researchers are racing to develop new weight-loss drugs that can surpass the effectiveness of Ozempic. These advancements could revolutionize obesity treatment and offer new options for weight management, with promising clinical developments underway.

stories.headline: An Ayatollah’s Fraught Choice: Backing Down or Ramping Up
stories.summary: The article explores the complex decisions faced by Iran's Supreme Leader, especially under pressures from regional and international conflict escalation. With the recent U.S. strike on Iran’s nuclear sites, there is intense speculating on whether Iran will back down or intensify its actions, with potential consequences for regional stability and diplomatic relations.

stories.headline: Tehran 'Reserves All Options' After Attack at Nuclear Sites
stories.summary: Iranian officials, including Foreign Minister Abbas Araghchi, have stated that Iran reserves all options to defend its sovereignty and interests following American strikes on its nuclear sites. Iran's military and allied forces have retaliated by attacking U.S. and allied bases in the Middle East, marking an escalation of tensions in the region. The Iranian government condemned the attacks as unjustified and vowed to respond accordingly.

stories.headline: A Dangerous Heat Wave
stories.summary: A severe heat wave is hitting the Midwest and Northeast, prompting officials to issue warnings and activate emergency measures to protect public safety during extreme temperatures.

stories.headline: No Extra Sleep for These Teens
stories.summary: New laws mandating later school start times for Florida schools will take effect soon, a change intended to improve teen sleep. The mandate faced opposition from some administrators but aims to enhance students’ health and academic performance.

stories.headline: Damage and defiance
stories.summary: Following U.S. airstrikes on Iran's nuclear sites, Iranian protesters gathered in Tehran expressing defiance and rallying under Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei's image. The U.S warned Iran of non-retaliation after the surgical strikes but acknowledged the potential for greater conflict. Iran's Revolutionary Guard threatened attacks on U.S. bases in the Middle East. The international situation remains tense with Iran's air defenses compromised and uncertain responses from allied militias and foreign actors.

stories.headline: Site dispute over trans athlete event
stories.summary: A conservative nonprofit is proceeding with a bus tour supporting the Trump administration's policies on transgender athletes despite a cancellation announcement from the planned host venue, Railyard. The nonprofit, Independent Women, led by Victoria Coley, insists the event called "Her Game. Her Legacy. Celebration of Title IX" is moving forward as planned. Amid controversy, clear communication and security arrangements for the event have been emphasized, with women and girls encouraged to attend this moment.

stories.headline: Another Trump Cabinet member joins lineup for governors’ event
stories.summary: Agricultural Secretary Rollins will speak at the Western Governors' Association meeting in downtown Santa Fe, which kicks off today. Deanna Archuleta plans to return to New Mexico from her work in Washington, D.C. Archuleta's experience and family ties to New Mexico make her a relevant participant in the event. The event will feature discussions on political, policy, and issues affecting powerful state and federal leaders, offering opportunities for consultation and influence.

stories.headline: County Commissioner Greene hopes to lead city
stories.summary: First-term County Commissioner Justin Greene is running for mayor of Santa Fe. He plans to make a formal announcement this week. Greene emphasized his unique qualifications and experience to address city issues. Raised in New York City and holding degrees from Syracuse University and the University of New Mexico, Greene has been active in Santa Fe since 1993. Despite challenges faced early on in Santa Fe, he is committed to pursuing the mayoral position.

stories.headline: State’s delegation denounces lack of congressional approval
stories.summary: New Mexico’s congressional delegation condemned President Donald Trump’s decision to order airstrikes on Iran without congressional authorization, arguing that it conflicts with the Constitution. The all-Democratic delegation urged a return to diplomacy and emphasized the need for congressional oversight on military actions. U.S. Rep. Teresa Leger Fernandez highlighted the importance of preserving American lives and military integrity by adhering to constitutional processes. The controversy reflects broader disputes over the scope of presidential powers in military decisions.

stories.headline: CentCom at the heart of mission
stories.summary: Gen. Michael “Erik” Kurilla is highlighted as a key figure in the secret bombing campaign targeting three Iranian nuclear sites. As the commander of U.S. Central Command, based at MacDill Air Force Base in Tampa, Kurilla plays a significant role in U.S. military operations in the Middle East. CentCom is responsible for military operations across 21 countries, including Iran and surrounding regions, and has been pivotal in overseeing precision strikes and countering threats such as Iran's nuclear ambitions.

stories.headline: Message mixed on bombing Iran
stories.summary: The Trump administration sent conflicting messages regarding an attack on three Iranian nuclear sites. Officials initially suggested a willingness for negotiations, but President Donald Trump posted online suggesting the regime should "MAKE IRAN GREAT AGAIN." The situation revealed internal disagreements within the administration about regime change and possible war with Iran, with key military and political figures expressing different views. Vice President JD Vance stated there was no intent for war, but Iran might seek negotiation.

stories.headline: Family, doctors reflect on 9-year-old’s recovery after shark attack
stories.summary: Leah Lendel, a 9-year-old who was bitten by a shark while snorkeling off Boca Grande, has shown remarkable recovery after surgeons at Tampa General Hospital quickly repaired her wrist and restored blood flow. The story recounts the traumatic incident and the swift medical response that saved her hand. Leah's family and medical professionals reflect on the experience, emphasizing the importance of emergency care and the child's resilience during recovery.

stories.headline: Iowa towing woes: cars towed, sold speedily
stories.summary: Chris Costa experienced firsthand the rapid towing and selling of cars in Iowa after his son's CR-V was towed for parking in a prohibited spot without available funds to retrieve it. Costa was unaware that Crow's Auto Service had sent a notice weeks prior and charged $380 for towing and storage. This story highlights the nationwide increase in complaints about insurance companies' towing practices, which have surged almost 90% over the past three years.

stories.headline: U.S. warns of ‘heightened threat environment’ after targeted strikes
stories.summary: Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth announced that U.S. bombers obliterated Iran’s three major nuclear complexes at Fordow, Natanz, and Isfahan in a targeted night strike on June 21. President Donald Trump declared Iran could face "far greater" attacks if it does not make peace with the United States and Israel, emphasizing that the U.S. is fully prepared to respond to any Iranian retaliation. The operations included a "highly classified mission" with B-2s and submarines.

stories.headline: Ames cosmetic surgeon Sturm files for bankruptcy
stories.summary: Ames cosmetic surgeon and anesthesiologist Lindsay Sturm has filed for Chapter 7 bankruptcy amid numerous malpractice lawsuits, including a wrongful death case involving a former patient. Sturm abruptly closed Sturm Cosmetic Surgery in February and voluntarily surrendered her medical license after being accused of professional incompetence. The bankruptcy filing lists liabilities exceeding $5.3 million, with debts owed to the IRS, student loans, and other lawsuits linked to unsafe practices and retaliation against a whistleblower.

stories.headline: Therapy dogs growing trend among schools
stories.summary: Schools in the Pittsburgh region are increasingly adopting therapy dogs to support student well-being and mental health. These trained animals provide comfort and help students manage stress and social challenges. The growing trend reflects awareness of mental health's importance in education and the innovative ways schools are responding to post-pandemic needs.

stories.headline: ALARM GROWS AFTER U.S. STRIKE
stories.summary: Following U.S. attacks on nuclear sites in Iran, protesters in Tehran held demonstrations expressing strong opposition, highlighting rising tensions and alarm over the U.S. strike. Iran's leadership declared the attack crossed a "very big red line," raising concerns over potential military responses and the security situation in the region.

stories.headline: Budget battle impacts county
stories.summary: Local government and nonprofit leaders across several Pennsylvania counties are closely monitoring the impact of ongoing federal budget negotiations on grant and program funding for the upcoming year. Recent submissions of right-to-know requests and county reports are highlighting concerns around equitable funding distribution and community needs, especially following pandemic-related stresses.

stories.headline: Drive for clean energy shifts
stories.summary: A year after efforts began to advance Pennsylvania's clean energy initiatives, advocates indicate that momentum is slowing. Despite legislative achievements like the Inflation Reduction Act of 2022 and incentives for solar, wind, and other green technologies, advocates and officials note challenges in maintaining the pace of transition amid changing political and economic factors.

stories.headline: Netanyahu: 'We are very close to achieving our goals'
stories.summary: The United Arab Emirates grappled with the U.S. military strike on Iran's nuclear sites, amid concerns over Iran’s response and the broader regional security implications. Iranian officials described the strike as highly provocative and warned of a proportional response. The conflict underscores the complex geopolitical tensions involving Israel, Iran, and U.S. strategies in the Middle East.

stories.headline: Jackson County homeowners can check accuracy of valuations
stories.summary: As Jackson County completes its 2025 property tax assessments, the Jackson County Assessor's Office released valuation notices to residents and started the re-assessment of 'real property' including land and buildings. The reassessment occurs biannually and affects properties based on odd or even-numbered years. County officials announced that the 2025 assessments would not increase more than 15%, even if market values grew more. This process follows legal requirements laid out by the Missouri State Tax Commission. Notices have been sent in batches for homeowners to verify the accuracy of their property valuations.

stories.headline: Royals’ stadium location may rely on mystery poll
stories.summary: As Missouri lawmakers weighed an incentives package to keep the Kansas City Chiefs and Royals inside state lines, speculation about polling related to the Royals and Clay County circulated. Top lawmakers involved in the debate, including the Republican bill sponsor and the Democrats, have given significance to an obscure poll that might influence the Royals' decision on whether to stay in Missouri or move to Kansas. The plan requires commitments from local governments and a poll in Clay County to decide if a new stadium can be funded in the Northland. However, officials are skeptical about the poll's validity and no clear details have been publicly shared.

stories.headline: North KC still trying to lure full-service grocery to town
stories.summary: For years, North Kansas City has been attempting to attract a full-service grocery store especially in the area near Armour Road and major interstates. A development project called One North was intended to help, but growth is slow and legal issues with developers have stalled progress. Despite setbacks, local officials remain hopeful and have focused on attracting stores like Trader Joe's to nearby Johnson County. The city's Save-a-Lot on Burlington Street offers some grocery options, but residents and officials want more variety and accessibility. Competition among grocery operators has intensified, with online delivery and specialty stores becoming factors.

stories.headline: Bombing Iran, Trump injects US into Middle East conflict
stories.summary: President Donald Trump announced that the U.S. military "totally obliterated" three of Iran's nuclear sites in response to a recent attack and potential threats. Trump claimed these strikes were in retaliation to Iran's hostility and stressed a message of peace while warning Iran of consequences if they retaliate. The bombings included underground facilities at Fordo and other significant military sites. The announcement came alongside remarks from high-level officials and emphasized a strong stance on nuclear threats and regional security.

stories.headline: A cool way to beat heat
stories.summary: As temperatures soar to an expected high of 82 degrees, eight-year-old Gabriel enjoys a refreshing splash at Fairview Park's wading pool in Minneapolis. Many people are finding ways to stay cool and seek relief from the weekend heat, with public pools and water parks seeing increased visitors. Forecasts suggest that cooler weather will start Monday, providing some respite from the heat wave.

stories.headline: School board policies butt up against culture clashes
stories.summary: Forest Lake's school board meetings have been marked by intense debates over dress codes and cultural issues, including a proposal on banning Confederate flags and swastikas. The discussions highlight the challenges of managing diversity and cultural sensitivities in education, with parents and students deeply divided. These conflicts reflect broader societal debates and have turned school policies into a contentious battleground for values and identity.

stories.headline: Shootings studied as ‘violent populism’
stories.summary: Federal charges have highlighted a worrying trend of violence linked to extremist political ideologies targeting Minnesota. Experts say the recent shootings, including the killing of a state representative and wounding of a senator, reflect a broader phenomenon described as 'violent populism' fueled by social and economic grievances. Law enforcement and political figures are trying to understand and address the root causes of these acts to curb further violence.

stories.headline: Alarm grows as U.S. steps into Iran conflict
stories.summary: The world is grappling with the United States' strike on Iran's nuclear sites, raising urgent concerns about the future of Tehran's nuclear program and global security. Experts warn that the effort to contain nuclear weapons through peaceful means is now at risk, with fears of a wider conflict escalating in the Middle East. Iran responded angrily, and U.S. officials emphasize the strikes are a proportionate response. The situation remains volatile and global markets have reacted to the uncertainty.

stories.headline: Trump strikes Iran, and the world waits for what’s next
stories.summary: President Donald Trump has ordered a significant military strike on Iran’s nuclear facilities, marking an unprecedented move in U.S. foreign policy. The strike aims to prevent Iran from developing a nuclear weapon but leaves much uncertainty about Iran's next response and the broader geopolitical consequences. The attack is described as both extraordinary and unprecedented, signaling a major shift in the Middle East's security landscape.

stories.headline: Trial will focus on ‘culture of officer impunity’ claim
stories.summary: An unusual civil trial is set to begin in Austin to examine whether the local police department fostered a 'culture of officer impunity' that contributed to the fatal shooting of a civilian in 2021. The case involves the shooting of Alex Gonzales Jr. by two Austin police officers, with family members filing a lawsuit invoking the Monell doctrine to hold the city liable if systemic misconduct by officers is proven. Legal experts note this trial addresses crucial issues surrounding police accountability and systemic abuse.

stories.headline: Bombing injects U.S. into Iran war
stories.summary: The United States has intensified its involvement in the conflict with Iran by launching early morning strikes that completely obliterated three Iranian nuclear sites. The strikes, dropping 30,000-pound bombs on a uranium enrichment site, raise concerns about how Iran might respond militarily, with Tehran potentially disrupting oil supplies and hitting military bases in retaliation. The decision marks a significant escalation in tensions in the Middle East and follows warnings from Iran's supreme leader to the U.S. to stay out of the conflict.
people: Iranian Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei

stories.headline: Abbott signs hundreds of bills as deadline looms
stories.summary: Texas Governor Greg Abbott signed approximately 600 proposed new laws on Saturday ahead of the legislative session deadline, including bills aimed at protecting abortions protections, banning the sale and consumption of intoxicating hemp products, and requiring posting of donated copies of the Ten Commandments in public schools. Uncertainty remains regarding the specifics of some plans and budget allocations, such as a $388 billion two-year spending plan requiring legislative approval.

stories.headline: Trump is now co-owner of the Israel-Iran war
stories.summary: The United States, under President Trump, has escalated involvement in the Israel-Iran conflict by bombing Iran's nuclear sites, marking a deeper engagement reminiscent of past conflicts like Iraq. The decision may trigger a broader regional war with unpredictable outcomes. Analysts recall the complexity of past wars as they assess current developments and warn of potential unknown consequences.

stories.headline: Region's senators, Congress members divided on strikes
stories.summary: Republicans praised President Trump's strike on Iran's nuclear sites, while Democrats largely criticized the move for lacking congressional approval. Some notable exceptions, such as Senator John Fetterman, highlighted the risks and potential consequences of the decision. The strike has stirred ongoing debate within the US Congress regarding the handling of foreign military actions and executive authority.

stories.headline: President is taking military and political risks
stories.summary: President Donald Trump's decision to strike Iran's nuclear enrichment facilities is a significant move that carries profound consequences for his presidency and the broader Middle East conflict. The decision breaks from previous presidents' approaches and could provoke retaliation. While it sends a strong message internationally, it might alienate some political supporters domestically.

stories.headline: U.S. calls damage from strikes severe
stories.summary: The United States has launched strikes against Iran's nuclear sites, prompting worldwide concerns about escalating conflict. Washington seeks diplomatic talks with Iran to prevent a wider war. Iran condemned the attacks, specifically highlighting the targeting of its key nuclear sites with missiles and bunker-buster bombs. The situation poses a risk for regional stability and global security, with fears of nuclear weapon escalation.

stories.headline: FBI: MN suspect a doomsday prepper
stories.summary: A Minnesota man suspected of killing a knife maker and her husband was identified as a doomsday prepper in police reports. The suspect allegedly shot four people during a hunt by authorities. The FBI stated the suspect's wife provided text messages indicating prepper plans, including current events, the need to evacuate, and people with guns potentially showing up at the house. The complaint was filed in U.S. District Court in Minnesota.

stories.headline: Residents sue Indy housing agency over security issue
stories.summary: Residents of a local public housing complex are suing their landlord and the Indianapolis Housing Agency (IHA) over security concerns, citing dangerous and filthy conditions including stairwells with feces and urine, a broken elevator, and violent crime problems near the property. The lawsuit accuses the landlord Richard G. Lugar Tower and the IHA of neglect and breach of lease and warranty of habitability. The plaintiffs argue that security is necessary to prevent unauthorized access through side doors.

stories.headline: ‘OBLITERATED’
stories.summary: Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth stated that U.S. bombers completely obliterated Iran's three major nuclear complexes at Fordow, Natanz, and Isfahan in a night strike on June 21. President Donald Trump announced the air strikes, warning Iran faces far greater attacks if peace is not achieved. Trump emphasized the strength and precision of the strikes and called for Iran to make peace, stating Israel cannot be allowed to obtain nuclear weapons. Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu also commented on the weakness of the Iranian regime.

stories.headline: Man gets life for 2023 killing
stories.summary: Jamal Barney has been sentenced to life in prison after being convicted for a killing that occurred in 2023. The sentencing concludes a high-profile murder case with significant impact on the local community.

stories.headline: Pittman elected as new chair
stories.summary: Anne Arundel County Executive Stewart Pittman was elected as the new chair of the Maryland Democratic Party. This leadership change comes ahead of upcoming elections and will shape the party's strategic direction moving forward.
people: Anne Arundel County Executive Stewart Pittman

stories.headline: Feral cats roam in masses
stories.summary: An estimated 86,000 to 185,000 cats live outdoors in Baltimore across approximately 660 city blocks. The significant feral cat population poses challenges to community animal control and public health, prompting discussion about humane management strategies and local initiatives to address the issue sustainably.

stories.headline: Sheriff, landowners resist in wake of power line ruling
stories.summary: In response to a court ruling granting PSEG access to private properties for a power line project, Carroll County Sheriff Jim DeWees and several landowners are resisting enforcement efforts. The opposition reflects local concerns about property rights and the impact of expanding infrastructure projects. The controversy highlights tensions between public utility development and private land ownership rights in Maryland.

stories.headline: NATO prepares for different summit
stories.summary: Europe faces shifting security dynamics with the ongoing war in Ukraine changing NATO's focus. The 2026 NATO summit, to be held in Vilnius, Lithuania, will likely have a different tone with a solidarity approach between member countries like Ukraine and support against Russian aggression. The U.S. administration and European allies are strategizing to bolster military and political support to Ukraine and neighboring countries as tensions persist in the region.

stories.headline: Trump floats idea of regime change in Iran
stories.summary: President Donald Trump on Sunday publicly considered questioning the future of Iran's ruling regime following a surprise attack on its nuclear sites, signaling reluctance to resume negotiations and emphasizing a tougher stance. The administration issued intimidating statements aimed at deterring Iran while trying to avoid escalation in ongoing conflicts between Israel and Iran. The move underscores the ongoing tension in the region and strategic positioning by the U.S.

stories.headline: 'Decisive action' or unconstitutional?
stories.summary: Maryland lawmakers, including U.S. Representative Andy Harris, reacted to recent U.S. military strikes on Iranian nuclear sites, supporting the decision as 'peace through strength.' President Donald Trump, who had previously advocated strongly for decisive military action, was highlighted for his role. While some see the strike as necessary, others question its constitutionality and long-term effects, reflecting a divided opinion on the president's use of military power.

stories.headline: Some see hope for revolution
stories.summary: In the wake of attacks on Iran's nuclear facilities, Iranian Americans in Maryland cautiously express optimism for potential regime change. Some believe the recent U.S. military strikes highlight the inability of Iran's regime to protect itself and might inspire revolt. However, others are wary, noting that the situation is complex and uncertain, with ongoing clashes and political ramifications. The story reflects the mixed feelings among Iranian Americans about the future of Iran.

stories.headline: Maryland GOP leaders balking at Moore's plan
stories.summary: Maryland Governor Wes Moore announced $400 million in state funds to historically underserved communities, but some Republican lawmakers criticize the initiative as an unproductive government handout. The funding, designated for DHCD's budgets over the next two fiscal years, aims to support Community Development projects with a focus on Priority Funding Areas. However, Republicans warn that the new scoring processes may produce unfair funding competitive disadvantages at Maryland taxpayers' expense.

stories.headline: Bill would limit how often school referendums occur
stories.summary: A proposed bill by Rep. Cindi Duchow and Sen. Chris Kapenga aims to restrict school districts' ability to hold recurring and non-recurring operating referendums to no more than once every four years. Currently, districts generally rely on renewing referendums indefinitely without expiration dates. The legislation seeks to regulate this process to better control education funding debates, sparking discussion as Democratic Gov. Tony Evers has requested increased education funding.

stories.headline: Hegseth calls attack powerful
stories.summary: Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth described U.S. bombers' strikes on Iran’s major nuclear sites at Fordow, Natanz, and Isfahan as 'powerful' and 'obliterating.' These attacks have prompted U.S. warnings about potential threats following the targeted strikes. President Donald Trump announced these attacks and praised American military efforts. The strikes were part of a night operation on June 21, dropping a full payload of bombs on the primary nuclear sites in Iran.

stories.headline: Tourist towns rattled
stories.summary: Foreign college students working in Door County under J-1 visas have heightened summer restaurant demand, causing wait times to stretch to three hours at popular locations like Al Johnson’s Swedish Restaurant. Many of these students stay for about three months, but a recent pause in student visas has alarmed local business owners who rely heavily on this summer workforce to accommodate the tourist influx.

stories.headline: Tax credit changes likely to impact solar companies
stories.summary: Proposed federal legislation could end solar tax incentives within six months, potentially clouding the future for the industry. The owner of Maine Solar Solutions noted steady business growth fueled by federal investments, but warned that the new residential solar system costs and expiration of incentives could slow progress. Discussions around future investment and policy adjustments are ongoing amid this evolving regulatory environment.

stories.headline: Mainers enjoy the first full sunny weekend in months
stories.summary: After a lengthy stretch of rainy Saturdays, Maine experienced a full sunny weekend bringing joy to many residents. Families gathered at local events and parks, enjoying music, swimming, and outdoor activities. Temperatures are expected to rise further during the upcoming week, with heat advisories possible for some regions. This weather change marks a significant shift from previous patterns, encouraging more outdoor recreation and community events.

stories.headline: MAINE LAWMAKERS RESPOND TO STRIKES
stories.summary: Maine's congressional delegates responded to the US strike on Iranian nuclear sites with mixed feelings of caution, criticism, and praise. While some highlighted the risks of escalating the conflict without congressional authorization, others emphasized the necessity of the strike to prevent Iran's nuclear development. The airstrike, involving 30,000-pound bombs on a mountain site, has raised fears of broader regional and extended conflicts.

stories.headline: US claims it caused ‘severe damage’ to Iran’s nuclear sites
stories.summary: During a morning news conference, Secretary of Defense Pete Hegseth stated that the US mission was not intended to cause regime change in Iran, but after President Donald Trump raised questions about Iran's nuclear sites and the potential for regime change, there is controversy over the administration's approach. The Defense Secretary detailed the aerial bombing of three major nuclear sites in Iran, indicating a significant escalation in US actions against Iran’s nuclear program.

stories.headline: Valley attractive to many
stories.summary: Metro Phoenix continues to attract significant interest from homebuyers seeking to relocate from larger cities across the country. The area's housing market momentum indicates growing demand, driven by lifestyle, affordability, and economic opportunity in the region.

stories.headline: Request for a grand jury
stories.summary: A judge is evaluating a request from Talyn Vigil, accused in Preston Lord's death, to transfer the case back to a grand jury. Vigil's lawyer contends that prosecutors violated client rights by presenting misleading evidence and omitting crucial facts. The decision on the grand jury request will impact the ongoing legal proceedings.

stories.headline: Teen gets probation in arson
stories.summary: A teenager was sentenced to probation after being found responsible for a barn-style guest house fire in Gilbert, following the remains of the burned building. Details on the case, including the reasons for probation, are covered in local court records.

stories.headline: How many Latino families support mass deportations by Trump?
stories.summary: A new poll reveals that nearly 70% of Latino families with children under age 5 in the U.S. oppose the mass deportations promoted by President Trump, although around 31% still support them. The study, conducted by BSP Research with national organization support, found the Trump campaign blamed immigrants for economic challenges, which has financially strained Latino communities more than others. The findings highlight tensions within the Latino community about immigration policies and their broader social and economic impacts.

stories.headline: Trump decision to strike Iran splinters state's political leaders
stories.summary: Arizona's political leaders showed division over President Donald Trump's choice to bomb three nuclear enrichment facilities in Iran, a decisive action that escalates U.S. involvement in the Middle East. GOP allies praised Trump’s decision, emphasizing trust and strategic necessity, while Democrats expressed strong opposition and concerns about the consequences for American lives and regional stability. The Republican Party of Arizona indicated support for the operation, while others like Rep. Ruben Gallego criticized it as reckless and urging immediate justification of the strikes.

stories.headline: 'OBLITERATED'
stories.summary: The U.S. Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth stated that U.S. bombers completely 'obliterated' Iran's three major nuclear complexes at Fordow, Natanz and Isfahan in a coordinated strike on June 21. President Donald Trump announced the air strikes on Iranian uranium enrichment sites and asserted that all plans are now outside Iran's air space. The operation underscores the high priority placed on the safety of U.S. service members and civilians amid increased tensions with Iran.

stories.headline: Michigan’s Fourth of July travel expected to be record-setting
stories.summary: AAA projects that Michigan will see record-setting travel during the Independence Day holiday, with over 2.6 million people expected to travel around the state throughout the holiday weekend, including 1.6 million traveling by car and nearly 5.84 million nationwide by car. AAA forecasts busy roads and airports, with 96,000 residents expected to fly domestically and over 160,000 traveling by bus, train or cruise. AAA advises travelers to plan vehicle maintenance and use available resources like the Michigan Department of Transportation’s road projects map and AAA's Tow To Go service.

stories.headline: Secrecy surrounds national park camper deaths
stories.summary: Multiple government agencies have refused to release details about the deaths of two campers found dead at a remote site in Michigan's Isle Royale National Park on June 8. Basic questions such as names, ages, and cause of death remain unanswered and secret due to withheld investigation records. The National Park Service will not disclose information about the ongoing investigation, and the Keweenaw County Medical Examiner’s office denied public records requests. A spokeswoman for the National Park Service said due to the ongoing investigation no additional information is being shared at this time.

stories.headline: Trump long warned of a ‘deep state’
stories.summary: As he traversed the country in 2024, Donald Trump pledged to supporters that voting him back into the presidency would be "our final battle." With persistent stoking of conspiracy theories involving his predecessors and other powerful politicians, Trump has urged his followers to expose a so-called "deep state," a supposed secret network manipulating government decisions behind the scenes. He has prioritized retribution against federal workers and legal professionals whom he blames for political rivals and the Jan. 6 attack on the U.S. Capitol, while denying evidence and retribution expected by others.

stories.headline: Vapes, Zyn, many tobacco products set for tax hikes
stories.summary: Illinois lawmakers have approved tax increases on a range of tobacco products, including vapes, Zyn, and traditional tobacco items. Effective July 1, the new rates will triple levies in many categories as part of efforts to reduce tobacco use. While some express concern about the impact on consumers, officials emphasize public health benefits.

stories.headline: Clean energy job training program offers hope: 'It's changed my life'
stories.summary: Eleven of sixteen clean energy job training hubs in Illinois are now operating, providing residents with opportunities in solar panel installation and other green technologies. The program, which includes physical training and hands-on experience, helps individuals like Jordan Foley gain skills and employment in the growing clean energy sector, supporting Illinois' climate goals.

stories.headline: Cooling off in the lake
stories.summary: Trey Shuey enjoys relief from a recent heat wave by diving into the water at North Avenue Beach in Chicago. The heat wave, which has affected the Chicago area, is expected to last until Monday, providing residents with summer warmth alongside opportunities for recreation at local beaches.

stories.headline: Illinois' borders unlikely to change
stories.summary: Despite efforts by Indiana lawmakers to alter state boundaries, Illinois' borders appear unlikely to change. The proposed Indiana-Illinois Boundary Adjustment Commission, though initiated by supporters, has faced criticism and is seen as a political stunt given constitutional requirements against forming new states or altering jurisdictions without mutual consent.

stories.headline: Trump posits Iran regime change
stories.summary: President Donald Trump questioned the future of Iran's ruling theocracy after a surprise attack on three of the country's nuclear sites, calling for regime change and escalating tensions. The Trump administration is seeking to resume negotiations but demands Iran stop nuclear weapons development amid recent bombings attributed to Iran.

stories.headline: Lawmaker disclosures leave out key details
stories.summary: Annual financial disclosures filed by Michigan lawmakers this month provided an incomplete picture of lobbyist perks. Many lawmakers failed to report actual values of gifts such as meals and tickets from lobbyists, which raises transparency concerns. A significant number of lawmakers reported receiving no benefits or only listed firms or interest groups without specifics. Examples include gifts like meals and event tickets, with some lawmakers reporting receiving perks without details about the purchases' value, highlighting gaps in disclosure requirements.

stories.headline: Trump gambles his presidency on war
stories.summary: President Donald Trump's decision to strike Iran's nuclear enrichment facilities is seen as an extraordinary risk that could have major consequences for his presidency. The move has divided GOP allies and raised concerns about further escalating conflict in the Middle East. Trump's decision marked a significant departure from his previous reluctance to engage in such military actions and signals a tough stance. The implications of the strike are being closely watched by global leaders and political analysts.

stories.headline: U.S. strikes Iran nuke sites as world asks, what's next?
stories.summary: The U.S. launched a massive strike on Iran's nuclear program, targeting three main nuclear sites with stealth attacks. The Trump administration stated that the attack was limited and not aimed at overthrowing Iran's government. Officials emphasized the goal of avoiding a regime change, wanting to negotiate a long-term settlement. Iran considered all options in response, while the U.S. prepared for diplomatic and military responses if needed.

stories.headline: Wayne church staff 'prevented a mass shooting'
stories.summary: A gunman wearing a tactical vest and carrying two guns targeted a suburban Detroit church, firing shots inside the building's exterior during a special vacation Bible School service. The gunman was run over by a church member with a vehicle and then fatally shot by church security. About 150 people were at a service, and police and church members acted quickly to prevent a large-scale mass shooting. The man appeared to be suffering from a mental health crisis.
people: CrossPointe Community Church Senior Pastor Bobby Kelly Jr.

stories.headline: A UFO Legend Lands Up at Elite Defense Lab
stories.summary: A piece of metal alleged to be from a spacecraft after a three-decade journey has been sent to a top Pentagon defense technology lab for analysis. The object is part of ongoing investigations into UFO phenomena, reflecting the Defense Department's interest in aerial phenomena and potential extraterrestrial technology. The story debunks some public UFO myths while pointing to serious defense research.

stories.headline: Thunder Win NBA Title
stories.summary: The Oklahoma City Thunder defeated the Indiana Pacers to win their first NBA championship title since relocating from Seattle. The victory marks a significant achievement for the team and their fans.

stories.headline: Premium Credit Cards Are Getting Even Pricier
stories.summary: JPMorgan Chase announced raising the annual fee for its Sapphire Reserve credit card by 45%, making it the most expensive popular premium credit card. The increase reflects a broader trend among card companies raising prices amidst changing economic conditions. The price hike is notable given the card's popularity and competition in the credit card market.

stories.headline: How Trump Got to 'Yes' on Military Mission
stories.summary: President Trump approved U.S. airstrikes on Iranian nuclear sites following discussions with top advisers and intelligence reports confirming Iran's role. The decisions were influenced by foreign policy complexities, concerns about nuclear proliferation, and a strategic aim to curb Iran's nuclear ambitions within a broader coalition effort in the Middle East. The operation was framed as a defensive move rather than an aggressive act.

stories.headline: U.S. Weighs Strikes' Damage in Iran
stories.summary: After hitting Iran's key nuclear facilities, U.S. officials describe the strikes as a one-off intervention with potential for further escalation depending on Iranian and Israeli actions. President Trump emphasized his desire for peace, but tensions remain high with Iran's nuclear program likely set back yet uncertain regarding enriched uranium. The Pentagon assessed the strike's impact, while political and military leaders prepare for possible prolonged conflict.

stories.headline: Birth tissue finds new uses at Mercy
stories.summary: A new program called Beginnings and Blessings at Mercy Health allows mothers to donate their placentas for medical use. The placentas, typically discarded as medical waste, are now used to nourish developing babies and aid in wound treatment, grafting, and research. Dr. Margaret Marcerndler, obstetrician at Mercy St. Louis, highlighted the innovative uses of this biological material that holds promise for various medical applications.

stories.headline: Bailey wants third-party social media moderators
stories.summary: Missouri Attorney General Andrew Bailey has proposed requiring major social media platforms like Facebook, Instagram, YouTube, and TikTok to allow third-party moderators to police content. This proposal faces criticism from First Amendment lawyers who argue it could weaken content control and face legal challenges. Bailey aims to combat corporate censorship online, but experts believe courts may reject the proposal as violating free speech protections.

stories.headline: HEAT WAVE LINGERS
stories.summary: A persistent heat wave continues to affect the region, prompting residents to seek relief by spending time at local rivers and pools. Steve Reardon and Tricia Kinman were seen enjoying the Meramec River with their dog, staying cool under the ongoing high temperatures impacting St. Louis County.

stories.headline: US claims ‘severe damage’ at Iran sites
stories.summary: The Trump administration sent a series of conflicting messages indicating a willingness to resume negotiations after a surprise attack on Iranian nuclear sites. U.S. President Donald Trump discussed the possibility of regime change but was cautious. Iranian President Masoud Pezeshkian condemned the U.S. strike as aggression and warned of a necessary response. The situation has raised tensions globally, with leaders urging restraint amid fears of escalation.

stories.headline: Parents, teachers jolted by plan to move 2 Seattle school programs
stories.summary: Seattle Public Schools proposed relocating two programs from a West Seattle building hit by bullets in February, causing mixed reactions from families and staff. The proposal affects programs serving adults with disabilities and students facing significant academic challenges. The plan was released mid-school year with limited time for families to explore options, leading to confusion and concerns about the suitability of the new sites. The district described the plans as proposals pending further discussion and input.

stories.headline: Rainier Avenue South residents weary of continued crashes
stories.summary: Residents on Rainier Avenue South have experienced a series of vehicle crashes over the years, with drivers hitting homes and parked cars on this busy 2-mile stretch in southeast Seattle. The community is concerned about speeding and erratic driving, with recent incidents causing property damage but no major injuries. Locals are hoping for increased safety measures to prevent further accidents.

stories.headline: With fateful decision, Trump gambles his presidency on war
stories.summary: President Donald Trump's decision to strike Iran's nuclear enrichment facilities is seen as a high-stakes move that could either eliminate a major threat or lead to prolonged conflict, potentially weakening his presidency. The move marks a significant foreign policy challenge reminiscent of past presidents, with uncertain outcomes and risks of escalating military involvement.

stories.headline: Trump not ruling out regime change in Iran
stories.summary: President Donald Trump raised questions about the future of Iran's ruling theocracy after a surprise attack on nuclear sites, contradicting the administration's previous stance and leaving open the possibility of regime change. The administration is also open to new negotiations regarding Iran's nuclear activities, despite the recent airstrikes. The situation remains complex with global ramifications.

stories.headline: Downtown is up with residents despite woes
stories.summary: Downtown Los Angeles continues to attract residents despite ongoing challenges. Residents like Ricardo Sebastián appreciate the vibrant, walkable community and lifestyle options such as casual dining and amenities, indicating a steady preference for city living while acknowledging existing issues.

stories.headline: As Hollywood struggles, CEO pay rises
stories.summary: Despite challenges facing the entertainment industry in 2024, including corporate struggles and widening income gaps with workers, executive compensation continues to climb. Warner Bros. Discovery’s CEO David Zaslav saw a 4% increase in his compensation package compared to the previous year, sparking criticism about pay inequality in Hollywood.

stories.headline: Anguish, hope in L.A. after airstrikes
stories.summary: The Iranian American community in Los Angeles is processing mixed and complicated feelings following recent airstrikes. Community members expressed a range of emotions from anger and hatred towards the Iranian regime to hope and resilience as they cope with the ongoing tensions and impacts on their lives.

stories.headline: Trump targets tuition benefits
stories.summary: The Trump administration is suing Texas and Kentucky over policies that allow undocumented students to pay in-state tuition rates. This legal battle challenges efforts to provide access to higher education for undocumented immigrants, raising questions about whether California could be next in the dispute.

stories.headline: Altadena raid stirs fears that sweeps will hinder rebuilding
stories.summary: After ICE agents raided a construction site of a burned property in Altadena, concerns arose about the impact on rebuilding efforts. The raid scared off workers, making it difficult to bring the project to completion, highlighting the critical role of immigrant labor which is particularly hard to replace post-fire.

stories.headline: After bombing 3 nuclear sites, U.S. braces for Iran’s retaliation
stories.summary: Pentagon officials report that precision strikes on Iran's enrichment program caused severe damage. Following President Trump's historic bombing of Iran’s nuclear facilities, Washington is preparing for possible unpredictable retaliation from Iran. Despite Iranian government downplaying the impact, U.S. military officials describe the damage as severe, marking a significant escalation in tensions.

stories.headline: Court limits NY oversight of private schools
stories.summary: A New York Court of Appeals ruled that the state education commissioner does not have the authority to determine if a private school offers substantially equivalent education compared to public schools. This limits the state's ability to enforce education standards on private schools, including religious yeshivas. Plaintiffs challenging New York's education laws include parents and educators, while advocacy groups on both sides of the issue continue to react to this significant decision.

stories.headline: New York for All Act left for dead
stories.summary: New York Governor Kathy Hochul faced criticism from Republican lawmakers over the state's sanctuary policies, with efforts to pass the New York for All Act stalling. The act, supported by Democrats, aims to protect undocumented immigrants by limiting cooperation with federal immigration enforcement. The bill is now postponed until the next session in 2026. Recent ICE raids in Manhattan and political repercussions for candidates associated with immigration issues highlight ongoing tensions.

stories.headline: U.S. on ‘high alert’ after attacking Iranian nuclear facilities
stories.summary: Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth announced that U.S. bombers completely 'obliterated' three major Iranian nuclear complexes in a night strike on June 21. The attacks targeted sites at Fordow, Natanz, and Isfahan, dropping a full payload of bombs. President Donald Trump stated this was a necessary response to Iran's potential threats, and the U.S. remains on high alert for possible retaliations from Tehran.

stories.headline: Routine traffic stops become major tool in ICE crackdown
stories.summary: Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) is increasingly using routine traffic stops as a method to detain individuals without proof of U.S. citizenship, a tactic that human rights advocates criticize as unfair profiling. Arrests at these stops have surged under recent administration policies.

stories.headline: As bees collapse, a key to their secrets might vanish
stories.summary: The decline of native bee populations threatens critical scientific research on these pollinators. Proposed federal budget cuts could defund a top federal laboratory dedicated to studying wild bees, impacting efforts to understand and protect these vital insects essential to ecosystems and agriculture.

stories.headline: Trump’s two weeks’ statement hid growing plan to attack, officials say
stories.summary: President Donald Trump reportedly delayed announcing a U.S. strike on Iran while plans were underway, a tactic that sowed confusion about his intentions. Officials reveal the administration was divided and cautious, with the attack executed after careful deliberations during those two weeks.

stories.headline: Weighing retaliation, regime in Tehran faces an existential choice
stories.summary: Iran confronts a significant decision following a U.S. strike on its nuclear facilities, balancing between diplomatic restraint or military retaliation. The Iranians face internal and external pressures about how to respond amid uncertainty about the attack's full impact and potential consequences for regional stability.

stories.headline: U.S. claims limited strike met its goals
stories.summary: The U.S. carried out an attack on Iran's nuclear facilities that was limited in scope and intended as a measured strike rather than an effort to overthrow the Iranian government. Satellite imagery shows damage to Iran's nuclear sites but the full extent remains unclear. Officials believe the operation achieved its objectives without escalating the conflict drastically.

stories.headline: HCC OKs name change of Houston City College
stories.summary: Houston Community College will be renamed Houston City College, reflecting a major shift as the 54-year-old institution expands its educational offerings to include bachelor's degrees. This decision was made at a board meeting despite some concerns over the $2.8 million cost. The change corresponds with a national trend of colleges rebranding to appeal more to students and employers.

stories.headline: Teacher pay in HISD up 11% since takeover; gains higher with NES
stories.summary: Mahogany Narcisse was appointed superintendent of Houston ISD in June 2023 amid significant changes in the district. Teacher pay has increased by 11% post-takeover, with even higher gains under the New Education Standards (NES). Despite initial nervousness about the rapid changes, teachers like Narcisse have found the adjustments manageable and see progress with leadership fostering comfort and growth.

stories.headline: Bombing injects U.S. into Iran war
stories.summary: The world faces urgent questions following the U.S. insertion into Israel's war against Iran with an attack that targeted Iranian nuclear sites. This has raised concerns about the future of nuclear non-proliferation and potential military escalation, with Iran threatening retaliation against oil supplies, American bases, and allies. The Trump administration emphasizes diplomacy despite the tensions. The situation remains volatile as assessments continue about the damage and the diplomatic fallout.
